flashcards.english: Ĩkĩĩra = put/pour for someone: Ĩkĩĩra Njeri cai (pour tea for Njeri). Gũthooma (to read) → Thomera = read to/for someone: Thoomera mwana ibuku (read a book to the child). Gũtwara (to deliver) → Twarĩĩra = deliver to/for somebody: Twarĩĩra maina irio (take food to Maina)
flashcards.notes: Benefactive suffix -ĩra/-era transforms verbs to mean 'do for/to someone'. Applied benefactive pattern: base verb + benefactive suffix. The suffix indicates the action benefits or is directed toward someone

flashcards.english: Class III nouns do not change form in plural. Singular: uses ĩno (this). Plural: uses ici (these). Example: Metha ĩno ĩmwe (this one table) vs Metha ici igĩrĩ (these two tables) - 'metha' stays the same
flashcards.notes: Class III includes objects, birds, reptiles, insects, and some mammals. Unlike Class I/II (people) which change form, Class III nouns remain invariant. Only demonstratives and numbers show plurality
